repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Second Magdalena Medio Regional
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Second Magdalena
            Medio Regional Development Project for Colombia were the
            following: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was highly likely, the institutional development impact was
            high, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that significant
            time is required to develop a model. Building blocks of
            local processes and clear rules for decision making had been
            instituted in the first Learning and Innovation Loan (LIL)
            but required continuing development. Continuing leadership
            from a recognized change agent remains important even as
            local units and communities become more empowered.
            Approaches need to be flexible and responsive to local
            differences. Monitoring and evaluation systems need plenty
            of time to develop and to demonstrate their usefulness at
            the local and central levels. Standard economic and social
            indicators may not be significantly sensitive to changes at
            the community level; alternative measures may need to be
            developed. Creating a climate of accountability among public
            and private entities is a long-term venture. Specialized
            expertise is needed for specific types of subproject
            support. Loan financing of subprojects is an important tool
            for financial sustainability. Even the most disadvantaged
            communities have untapped stores of local vision and
            leadership that can be mobilized through flexible and
            responsive approaches.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Second Magdalena Medio Regional
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main development objective of the
            Second Magdalena Medio Regional Development Project, is to
            test new forms of managing, and operating the Program for
            Development and Peace in the region, to unravel a more
            influential citizenry, able to rely on responsive local
            institutions, and able to enjoy tangible socioeconomic
            benefits. Project components will: 1) support the
            Corporation for Development and Peace Magdalena Medio's
            program leadership role, by covering its core costs, and
            incremental costs of offices, consultant services, and
            related training, equipment, and operating costs. The
            program will increase the role of community organizations,
            will take into account the regional diversity, particularly
            the armed conflict, and, will gradually decrease dependence
            on the Corporation, who will transfer capacity, and
            decision-making to regional organizations; 2) strengthen
            local, and regional institutions, to improve accountability,
            with particular attention to municipalities, by developing
            information databases, and developing groups capacity to
            influence policies, plans, and programs within the municipal
            administration, with particular attention to the health
            sector; 3) identify productive subprojects, concerning
            improvements in small peasant farming practices, development
            of agro-industrial projects, and small businesses, aiming at
            employment, an income generation, supported by technical
            assistance, and training; and, 4) finance social subprojects
            in vulnerable communities, addressing food security, primary
            health care, and basic education.
